title: Integrate route mode into Game.tsx, GameHUD, and GameUI
Define route-specific types
description:
Define all types needed by route mode. These are referenced by every subsequent route mode bead.

CREATE NEW FILE: game/route/types.ts

Types to define:

1. RouteAddress — a start/end address definition (no lat/lng — those come from Snap to Roads API at runtime)
   ```ts
   type RouteAddress = {
     name: string      // e.g. "Jacob Aalls gate 32"
     roadName: string  // e.g. "Jacob Aalls gate"
   }
   ```

2. SnappedAddress — a RouteAddress after geocoding + road-snapping
   ```ts
   type SnappedAddress = RouteAddress & {
     lat: number
     lng: number
   }
   ```

3. SelectedIntersection — a single player decision (one click)
   ```ts
   type SelectedIntersection = {
     intersectionId: number
     lat: number
     lng: number
     fromRoadName: string   // road the player was on when clicking
     toRoadName: string     // road the player entered (may be same road if continuing straight)
   }
   ```

4. RouteGameState — the core mutable game state (NOT a discriminated union — game phase is derived from this data)
   ```ts
   type RouteGameState = {
     startAddress: SnappedAddress
     endAddress: SnappedAddress
     currentRoadName: string
     currentIntersectionId: number | null  // null = on starting road, haven't clicked yet
     path: SelectedIntersection[]          // ordered clicks; undo = pop (not implemented in v1)
   }
   ```
   Game phase derivation:
   - `path.length === 0` → at start (show starting road intersections)
   - destination road reachable from current intersection → show end marker as clickable
   - otherwise → mid-route

5. RouteResult — computed after game ends, from Google Maps Compute Routes API
   ```ts
   type RouteResult = {
     playerRouteTimeSeconds: number
     optimalRouteTimeSeconds: number
     differenceSeconds: number
     playerRoutePolyline: string   // encoded polyline from Compute Routes response
     optimalRoutePolyline: string  // encoded polyline from Compute Routes response
   }
   ```

IMPORTANT DESIGN NOTES:
- RouteAddress intentionally has NO lat/lng. The spec says coordinates are fetched at runtime via Snap to Roads API. SnappedAddress is the resolved version.
- The path array is append-only in v1 (no undo). But its design (ordered array with pop semantics) makes undo trivial to add later.
- Do NOT create a discriminated union state machine for game phases. The issue spec explicitly says "All game phases are derived" from the data. Phase is a computed property, not stored state.
- Polylines in RouteResult are Google's encoded polyline format (string). They'll be decoded for rendering on the results screen.

VALIDATION:
- All types exported
- No runtime code in this file — types only
- TypeScript compiles clean

title: Google Maps address geocoding and Snap to Roads API
description:
API functions to resolve a RouteAddress (name + roadName, no coordinates) into a SnappedAddress (with precise road-snapped lat/lng).

CREATE NEW FILE: api/snapToRoads.ts

TWO-STEP PROCESS:
1. Geocode the address string to get approximate lat/lng
2. Snap that lat/lng to the nearest road via Google Maps Roads API (Snap to Roads)

STEP 1 — GEOCODING:
- Use the Google Maps Geocoding API (REST): `https://maps.googleapis.com/maps/api/geocode/json?address=<address>,+Oslo,+Norway&key=<key>`
- OR use the Places API (already loaded in GoogleMapsProvider as 'places' library) via `google.maps.places.PlacesService` or the newer `Place.searchByText()`
- The REST approach is simpler and doesn't require a map instance. Prefer REST.
- API key: use `fetchGoogleMapsApiKey()` from `utils/googleMapsApiKey.ts` (already memoized)

STEP 2 — SNAP TO ROADS:
- Google Maps Roads API endpoint: `https://roads.googleapis.com/v1/snapToRoads?path=<lat>,<lng>&key=<key>`
- Takes the geocoded lat/lng and returns the nearest point on the road network
- Response includes `snappedPoints[0].location.latitude` and `.longitude`
- If the Roads API is not available or fails, fall back to the geocoded coordinates (they're usually close enough for marker placement)

FUNCTION SIGNATURE:
```ts
export const resolveAddress = async (address: RouteAddress): Promise<SnappedAddress>
```

Takes a RouteAddress, returns a SnappedAddress with lat/lng populated.

IMPORTANT:
- Both APIs use the same API key as the Maps JS API (fetched via fetchGoogleMapsApiKey)
- Use fetchWithSessionRetry from game/hooks/useFeaturesInPlay.ts for the REST calls (handles 401 session retry). NOTE: fetchWithSessionRetry is currently in a hook file — import it directly, it's a standalone async function despite its location.
- Add `credentials: 'include'` to fetch calls for session cookies
- The Roads API (Snap to Roads) requires the "Roads API" to be enabled in the Google Cloud project. If it returns a 403/permission error, document this clearly in the error message so the developer knows to enable it.
- Handle errors gracefully: if geocoding fails, throw with a clear message. If snap-to-roads fails, fall back to geocoded coordinates.

VALIDATION:
- Calling resolveAddress({ name: "Jacob Aalls gate 32", roadName: "Jacob Aalls gate" }) returns a SnappedAddress with valid Oslo coordinates (approximately lat: 59.93, lng: 10.73)
- The returned coordinates are on or very near the actual road

title: Google Maps Compute Routes API integration
description:
API functions for scoring the player's route at game end. Compares player's chosen path to Google Maps' optimal route.

CREATE NEW FILE: api/computeRoutes.ts

TWO API CALLS AT GAME END:

1. OPTIMAL ROUTE: A → B direct
   - POST https://routes.googleapis.com/directions/v2:computeRoutes
   - Headers: `X-Goog-Api-Key: <key>`, `X-Goog-FieldMask: routes.duration,routes.polyline.encodedPolyline`
   - Body: `{ origin: { location: { latLng: { latitude, longitude } } }, destination: { location: { latLng: { latitude, longitude } } }, travelMode: "DRIVE" }`
   - Returns: `routes[0].duration` (string like "1234s"), `routes[0].polyline.encodedPolyline`

2. PLAYER'S ROUTE: A → waypoints → B
   - Same endpoint, but with `intermediates` array containing the player's selected intersections as waypoints
   - Body adds: `intermediates: [{ location: { latLng: { latitude, longitude } } }, ...]`
   - The intermediates are the player's SelectedIntersection[] path, mapped to lat/lng
   - Returns same fields: duration + encoded polyline

FUNCTION SIGNATURES:
```ts
export const computeOptimalRoute = async (
  start: SnappedAddress,
  end: SnappedAddress,
): Promise<{ durationSeconds: number; encodedPolyline: string }>

export const computePlayerRoute = async (
  start: SnappedAddress,
  end: SnappedAddress,
  waypoints: Array<{ lat: number; lng: number }>,
): Promise<{ durationSeconds: number; encodedPolyline: string }>

export const computeRouteResult = async (
  start: SnappedAddress,
  end: SnappedAddress,
  playerPath: SelectedIntersection[],
): Promise<RouteResult>
```

`computeRouteResult` is the main entry point — calls both, computes the difference, returns a RouteResult.

IMPORTANT DETAILS:
- The Compute Routes API is a REST API (NOT the legacy Directions API). Use the v2 endpoint.
- API key from fetchGoogleMapsApiKey() in utils/googleMapsApiKey.ts
- The `X-Goog-FieldMask` header is REQUIRED — without it, the API returns an error. Request only the fields you need (duration and polyline).
- Duration is returned as a string like "1234s" — parse to number of seconds.
- The encoded polyline will be decoded later (in the results screen bead) for rendering. Just store the string.
- If the player's path has many waypoints (>25), the API has a limit. For v1 this is unlikely to be an issue with Oslo addresses. But add a comment noting the limit.
- Use fetchWithSessionRetry for the REST calls. Add credentials: 'include'.
- Route times are for DRIVING mode (travelMode: "DRIVE").

VALIDATION:
- computeRouteResult returns a RouteResult with all fields populated
- optimalRouteTimeSeconds <= playerRouteTimeSeconds (player's route is always >= optimal)
- Both encoded polylines are non-empty strings
- differenceSeconds = playerRouteTimeSeconds - optimalRouteTimeSeconds

SEEDED PAIR SELECTION:
```ts
export const selectRoutePair = (addresses: RouteAddress[], seed: string): { start: RouteAddress, end: RouteAddress }
```

- The seed comes from Redux gameSettings.seed (8-char alphanumeric string).
- With 2 addresses: seed determines which is A (start) and which is B (end). Same seed = same assignment every time.


- getRoutePair("abcd1234") and getRoutePair("xxxx9999") may return different results (different assignment of A/B)
- With 2 addresses, it always returns both (just swapping start/end based on seed)

title: Road graph cache hook (useRoadGraph)
description:
Custom hook that manages the client-side road data cache. This is the data engine that powers route mode gameplay — it fetches intersection data progressively as the player navigates.

CREATE NEW FILE: game/route/useRoadGraph.ts

HOOK SIGNATURE:
```ts
export const useRoadGraph = (): {
  roadCache: Map<string, RoadInfo>         // all fetched road data
  fetchedRoads: Set<string>                // roads fetched as PRIMARY query target
  isLoading: boolean                       // true while any fetch is in flight
  fetchRoad: (roadName: string) => Promise<void>  // fetch a road and its branches
  getIntersectionsForRoad: (roadName: string) => RoadIntersection[]  // lookup from cache
  reset: () => void
}
```

CORE LOGIC:

1. ROAD CACHE: A Map<string, RoadInfo> that accumulates ALL road data received from the API.
   - The API response for a single road query returns that road PLUS all roads branching from its intersections (pre-fetched for responsiveness).
   - So a single fetch populates multiple entries in the cache.

2. FETCHED ROADS TRACKING: A Set<string> that tracks which roads have been fetched as the PRIMARY query target (i.e., the road_name param in the API call).
   - A road appearing as a BRANCH in another road's response does NOT count as fetched.
   - WHY: The branch data only includes intersections with the queried road. To get a road's FULL intersection list (all its intersections with all other roads), you must fetch it as the primary target.
   - This distinction is critical for correct gameplay: when the player enters a new road, ALWAYS fetch it as primary target even if it's already partially in the cache from a branch response.

3. FETCH FUNCTION:
   ```ts
   const fetchRoad = async (roadName: string) => {
     if (fetchedRoads.has(roadName)) return  // already fetched as primary
     setIsLoading(true)
     const response = await fetchRoadWithIntersections('Oslo, Norway', roadName)
     // response is Record<string, RoadInfo> — merge ALL entries into roadCache
     // add roadName to fetchedRoads set
     setIsLoading(false)
   }
   ```
   Uses fetchRoadWithIntersections from api/roadData.ts (already exists).

4. INTERSECTION LOOKUP:
   ```ts
   const getIntersectionsForRoad = (roadName: string): RoadIntersection[] => {
     return roadCache.get(roadName)?.intersections ?? []
   }
   ```

STATE MANAGEMENT:
- Use useState for roadCache (Map) and fetchedRoads (Set). When updating, create new Map/Set instances to trigger re-renders.
- isLoading tracks in-flight fetches. If multiple fetches are concurrent, isLoading stays true until all complete.
- reset() clears both roadCache and fetchedRoads, sets isLoading to false.

IMPORTANT:
- Do NOT use useMemo/useCallback — React Compiler handles memoization automatically (per project CLAUDE.md).
- The hook does NOT trigger any fetches on its own. The consumer (useRouteMode) calls fetchRoad() when needed.
- Error handling: if a fetch fails, log the error and leave the cache unchanged. Don't crash the game.
- The RoadInfo and RoadIntersection types are imported from api/roadData.ts (already defined there).

VALIDATION:
- After fetchRoad("Jacob Aalls gate"), roadCache contains "Jacob Aalls gate" plus branching roads
- fetchedRoads contains only "Jacob Aalls gate" (not the branches)
- Calling fetchRoad("Jacob Aalls gate") again is a no-op (already in fetchedRoads)
- getIntersectionsForRoad returns the correct intersection list
- reset() clears everything

title: Route game state machine hook (useRouteMode)
description:
Core game logic hook for route mode. Composes useRoadGraph + address selection + Snap to Roads into a playable game loop. This is the route mode equivalent of useGameState.

CREATE NEW FILE: game/route/useRouteMode.ts

HOOK SIGNATURE:
```ts
export const useRouteMode = (seed: string): {
  // State
  startAddress: SnappedAddress | null     // null until geocoded + snapped
  endAddress: SnappedAddress | null       // null until geocoded + snapped
  currentRoadName: string | null          // null until initialized
  currentIntersectionId: number | null    // null = on starting road, no click yet
  path: SelectedIntersection[]            // player's click history
  isLoading: boolean                      // true during init (geocoding + first road fetch)
  isComplete: boolean                     // true when player reaches destination
  isGameActive: boolean                   // true once first click made and not complete

  // Available choices for current position
  availableIntersections: RoadIntersection[]

  // Actions
  handleIntersectionClick: (intersection: RoadIntersection) => void
  reset: () => void
}
```

INITIALIZATION FLOW (runs on mount / seed change):
1. Call getRoutePair(seed) to get start/end RouteAddress
2. Call resolveAddress() for both addresses (from api/snapToRoads.ts) — these can be parallel
3. Fetch the starting road: roadGraph.fetchRoad(startAddress.roadName)
4. Set currentRoadName = startAddress.roadName
5. isLoading = false — map can now render

The map MUST remain hidden (spinner) until step 5 completes. The consumer (Game.tsx) uses isLoading to control the spinner.

GAMEPLAY LOGIC — handleIntersectionClick(intersection):

1. APPEND to path:
   ```ts
   const decision: SelectedIntersection = {
     intersectionId: intersection.id,
     lat: intersection.lat,
     lng: intersection.lng,
     fromRoadName: currentRoadName,
     toRoadName: intersection.otherRoadName,
   }
   path.push(decision)  // (via setState — create new array)
   ```

2. UPDATE POSITION:
   - If intersection.otherRoadName === currentRoadName: player is continuing on the same road, just moved to a new intersection
     - currentIntersectionId = intersection.id
   - If intersection.otherRoadName !== currentRoadName: player is turning onto a new road
     - currentRoadName = intersection.otherRoadName
     - currentIntersectionId = intersection.id
     - Trigger: roadGraph.fetchRoad(intersection.otherRoadName) — fetch the new road's full data

3. CHECK FOR COMPLETION:
   - After updating position, check if the destination is now reachable
   - Destination is reachable when: the end address's roadName appears as an otherRoadName in one of the intersections at the current position
   - When reachable, the destination marker becomes clickable (handled by the map rendering bead)
   - If the player clicks the destination marker, isComplete = true

AVAILABLE INTERSECTIONS (derived state):
- When currentIntersectionId is null (at start): return ALL intersections of the starting road
- When currentIntersectionId is set: return intersections reachable from that position
  - This means: all intersections of currentRoadName that are "ahead" of the current position (direction committed)
  - PLUS: all intersections of connected roads at the current intersection (i.e., the player can see intersections down connecting roads, not just the next one)

DIRECTION COMMITMENT:
- When the player clicks an intersection, they commit to a direction on the current road.
- Intersections "behind" the selected intersection (on the same road) disappear from available choices.
- "Behind" is determined by the intersection's position relative to the last clicked intersection along the road's intersection list.
- Implementation approach: filter the current road's intersections to only those between the current position and the road's endpoints (in the direction of travel). The exact definition of "ahead" vs "behind" can use the intersection order in the RoadInfo.intersections array, or geographic distance. The intersection array order from the API may not be geographically ordered — investigate this. If not ordered, use geographic proximity to determine direction.

END DETECTION:
- At each position, check all intersections reachable from currentIntersectionId
- For each intersection, check if its otherRoadName === endAddress.roadName
- If yes, the destination road is reachable — mark it so the map rendering can show the end marker as clickable
- Expose a derived boolean: `isDestinationReachable` — true when the player can see/click the destination

RESET:
- Clear path, reset currentRoadName/currentIntersectionId to null
- Call roadGraph.reset()
- Re-run initialization with the same seed (or accept a new seed)

IMPORTANT NOTES:
- Do NOT store game phase as explicit state. Derive it: `path.length === 0` → start, `isComplete` → end, otherwise → mid-route. This is per the spec.
- The hook reads the seed from its parameter. The consumer gets the seed from Redux gameSettings.
- useEffect for initialization should be a named function (per project coding standards).
- Error handling: if address resolution or initial road fetch fails, set an error state and surface it. Don't silently fail.
- This hook is complex. Keep it well-organized: initialization logic, click handler, derived state computations, each in clear sections.

VALIDATION:
- On mount with a valid seed, isLoading transitions from true → false after init completes
- startAddress and endAddress are populated with lat/lng
- availableIntersections returns the starting road's intersections initially
- Clicking an intersection updates path, currentRoadName, currentIntersectionId
- After clicking, intersections behind the player disappear from availableIntersections
- When destination road is reachable from current position, isDestinationReachable is true
- reset() returns everything to initial loading state

title: Map rendering: intersection dots, A/B markers, route polyline
description:
Map visualization layer for route mode gameplay. Renders intersection dots, start/end markers, and the player's route polyline on the Google Map.

CREATE NEW FILE: game/route/useRouteMapRendering.ts (hook that manages all map objects)

This hook takes the route game state + a map instance and imperatively manages Google Maps objects (markers, polylines). It is the route mode equivalent of useGameStyling + useFeatureLabels.

HOOK SIGNATURE:
```ts
export const useRouteMapRendering = ({
  map,
  AdvancedMarkerElement,
  routeState,          // return value of useRouteMode
  onIntersectionClick, // callback when player clicks a dot
  onDestinationClick,  // callback when player clicks the end marker
}: Props): {
  isMapReady: boolean  // true once initial rendering is complete
}
```

VISUAL ELEMENTS:

1. START MARKER (A):
   - Position: startAddress lat/lng
   - Always visible from game start to end
   - Green or labeled "A" — use AdvancedMarkerElement with a custom HTML element (colored circle with letter)
   - Not interactive (just a label)

2. END MARKER (B):
   - Position: endAddress lat/lng
   - Always visible from game start to end
   - Red or labeled "B" — same pattern as A marker
   - Becomes CLICKABLE when isDestinationReachable is true (visual change: glow, larger, cursor pointer)
   - When clicked: calls onDestinationClick

3. INTERSECTION DOTS:
   - One dot per intersection in routeState.availableIntersections
   - Default: white/off-white small circles (use AdvancedMarkerElement with custom HTML — a styled div with border-radius: 50%)
   - On hover: expand slightly (CSS transform: scale(1.3) or similar)
   - When clicked: turn blue and remain visible permanently (even after new dots appear)
   - Already-selected intersections (in routeState.path) are always shown as blue dots
   - Dots that are no longer in availableIntersections should be removed from the map (they were "behind" the player and disappeared after direction commitment)
   - Each dot must be clickable — attach click listener that calls onIntersectionClick(intersection)

4. ROUTE POLYLINE:
   - Blue line drawn through all selected intersections in path order
   - Starts at startAddress position, goes through each SelectedIntersection lat/lng
   - Use google.maps.Polyline with strokeColor: '#4285F4' (Google blue), strokeWeight: 4
   - Update the polyline path whenever routeState.path changes

5. INITIAL ZOOM:
   - After initial data loads (startAddress + endAddress + starting road intersections are all available):
   - Compute bounds that fit: startAddress, endAddress, AND all starting road intersection points
   - Call map.fitBounds(bounds) with some padding
   - After this initial fit, the player can freely pan/zoom (don't re-fit on subsequent interactions)

MAP OBJECT LIFECYCLE:
- Use useEffect (named functions per project standards) to sync map objects with state
- When routeState changes, diff the visual state:
  - Add new dot markers for new available intersections
  - Remove dot markers for intersections no longer available
  - Update polyline path
  - Update end marker clickability
- On unmount / reset: clean up all markers and polylines (remove from map, clear references)
- Keep references to all created map objects so they can be updated/removed. Use a Map<number, AdvancedMarkerElement> keyed by intersectionId for dots.

SPINNER:
- The map should be hidden behind a spinner until routeState.isLoading is false AND initial zoom is set
- This matches the existing pattern in Game.tsx where GMap has spinUntilReady
- isMapReady should be true once initial rendering is complete

IMPORTANT:
- AdvancedMarkerElement is passed in (from GMap's onMapReady callback). Use it for all markers.
- google.maps.Polyline is available from the core Maps JS API (no extra library needed).
- For dot hover effects: use CSS transitions on the custom HTML element inside AdvancedMarkerElement. The element is a regular DOM element, so standard CSS works.
- Do NOT use the map.data layer (that's for GeoJSON polygons used by click/name mode). Route mode uses direct markers + polylines.
- This hook will need the map instance. The consumer (Game.tsx route branch) gets it from GMap's onMapReady callback.

VALIDATION:
- A and B markers appear at correct positions on game start
- Starting road's intersections appear as white dots
- Hovering a dot makes it expand
- Clicking a dot turns it blue and triggers onIntersectionClick
- Blue polyline extends through selected intersections
- Dots behind the player disappear after clicking
- When destination is reachable, B marker changes visual state
- Initial zoom shows A, B, and all starting intersections in view
- All markers/polylines are cleaned up on reset
